name: hydrazinecarboxamide, n-phenyl-
Reason: 1,3-Diphenylpropane has a melting point of 100.5 °C. The introduction of a carboxamide group (-CO-NH2) generally increases the melting point due to the potential for hydrogen bonding and dipole-dipole interactions, estimated at around +10 °C. The presence of a phenyl group in the structure also raises the melting point due to increased molecular weight and rigidity, estimated at around +20 °C.
